from the 35th District | term_start1 = January 1, 2004 | term_end1 = December 31, 2013 | predecessor1 = [[James E. Davis (councilman)|James E. Davis]] | successor1 = [[Laurie Cumbo]] | constituency1 = [[Brooklyn]]: [[Clinton Hill, Brooklyn|Clinton Hill]], [[Fort Greene]]; parts of [[Crown Heights, Brooklyn|Crown Heights]], [[Prospect Heights, Brooklyn|Prospect Heights]], [[Bedford-Stuyvesant]]. | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1958|10|18}} | birth_place = [[Brooklyn, New York]], U.S. | nationality = American | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]]
[[Working Families Party]] | residence = [[Clinton Hill, Brooklyn]] | alma_mater = [[Lehman College]]
[[Howard University School of Law|Howard University]] | profession = {{hlist|Lawyer|activist|politician}} | website = [http://council.nyc.gov/d35/html/members/home.shtml NYC Council: District 35] }} '''Letitia A.''' "'''Tish'''" '''James''' (born October 18, 1958){{cite web|last=Kravitz |first=Derek |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424127887323665504579027181873726784.html |title=Candidate's Age Often Listed Incorrectly - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=2013-08-22 |accessdate=2014-01-02}} is an American lawyer, [[activist]], and politician in the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]].{{cite news|url=http://www.dailykos.com/story/2013/09/23/1240832/-Oct-1-Runoff-Election-Planned-Parenthood-Gloria-Steinem-and-NOW-endorse-Tish-James-for-NYC|title=Oct. 1 Runoff Election: Planned Parenthood, Gloria Steinem and NOW endorse Tish James for NYC|publisher=Daily Kos}} She is the current and fourth [[New York City Public Advocate]] and first [[African American]] woman to hold citywide office. She previously served as a member of the [[New York City Council]], representing [[Brooklyn]]'s 35th Council District, which includes the neighborhoods of [[Clinton Hill, Brooklyn|Clinton Hill]], [[Fort Greene]], parts of [[Crown Heights, Brooklyn|Crown Heights]], [[Prospect Heights, Brooklyn|Prospect Heights]], and [[Bedford-Stuyvesant]]. James has also chaired the Economic Development and Sanitation Committees, and serves on the committees for Parks & Recreation, Small Business, Technology in Government, Veteran Affairs, and Women's Issues. In [[New York City Public Advocate election, 2013|2013]], James ran for [[New York City Public Advocate]] and received 36% of the vote in the first Democratic primary, under the 40% threshold to avoid a [[two-round system|runoff election]].{{cite news|url=http://project.wnyc.org/election2013/|title=Election 2013: Other Races}} However, James won the Democratic runoff on October 1, 2013 against [[Daniel Squadron]], 59%–41%, becoming the party's nominee for the city's elected watchdog position in November. Without a Republican opponent, James subsequently won the general election with over 83% of the vote.{{cite web|title=Letitia James wins NYC Public Advocate Democratic runoff|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=news/politics&id=9268206|publisher=WABC TV|accessdate=2 October 2013}} ==Early life and education== James was born in [[Brooklyn]], [[New York City|New York]], the daughter of Nellie and Robert James.[http://justlikedat.com/tish/tish.html The Candidate: A letter from Letitia "Tish" James]. Letitia James 2003 Campaign Website. She attended New York City [[Public school (government funded)|public schools]] and received her [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] from the [[City University of New York]]'s [[Lehman College]] in 1981.{{cite web|url=http://www1.cuny.edu/portal_ur/content/womens_leadership/alumnae/index.html|title=Distinguished CUNY Alumnae|publisher=The City University of New York|accessdate=2009-05-07}} James graduated from the [[Howard University School of Law]] in [[Washington, D.C.]][http://council.nyc.gov/d35/html/members/home.shtml James' profile at the NYC Council website] and was admitted to practice law in New York state in 1989.{{cite web|url=http://iapps.courts.state.ny.us/attorney/AttorneyDetails?attorneyId=5455915|title=NYS Attorney Registration}} She is attending [[Columbia University|Columbia]]'s [[School of International and Public Affairs, Columbia University|School of International and Public Affairs]] for a degree in [[Master of Public Administration]].{{cite web|url=http://www.letitiajames2013.com/about_tish|title=About Tish|publisher=Letitia James 2013}} ==Career== James served as a [[public defender]] for the [[Legal Aid Society]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nyccfb.info/public/voter-guide/general_2003/cd_statement/CD35_James_480.htm|title=2003 General Election Voter Guide: 35th City Council District|publisher=NYC Campaign Finance Board}} and established the Urban Network, a coalition of [[African American]] professional organizations aimed at providing scholarships for young people.{{cite web|url=http://wccny.org/2012/03/20/april-23-lunch-with-legislators-councilmember-letitia-james/|title=April 23 – Lunch with Legislators: Council Member Letitia James|publisher=Women's City Club of New York}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nyccfb.info/public/voter-guide/primary_2013/cd_profile/PA_James_480.aspx|title=Candidates for Public Advocate: Democratic Primary|publisher=NYC Campaign Finance Board}} In 1994, she promoted the Primary Health Case Development Bill in the City Council, which expanded [[day care]] resources for [[working poor|working families]] across the city. In 1996, James negotiated the [[Welfare Reform]] Act on behalf of the [http://www.nysenate.gov/committee/new-york-state-black-puerto-rican-hispanic-and-asian-legislative-caucus New York State Black and Puerto Rican Caucus]. She served on former New York Governor [[Mario Cuomo]]'s Task Force on [[Multiculturalism|Diversity]] in the Judiciary. She served as [[counsel]] for [[Albert Vann]], [[Chief of staff (politics)|Chief of Staff]] for [[Roger L. Green]] in the [[New York State Assembly]], and in the administration of [[New York Attorney General]] [[Eliot Spitzer]]. She was appointed the first Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Brooklyn regional office in 1999. While working in that position, James worked in many capacities but notably focused on consumer complaints involving [[predatory lending]] and other unlawful business practices. === 2001 and 2003 City Council races === James' first run for the 35th Council District was in November 2001. In a close race, James received 42% of the vote on the [[Working Families Party]] line but lost to [[James E. Davis (councilman)|James E. Davis]], a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]]. In July 2003, just months before the next election, Davis was assassinated by [[Othniel Askew]], another politician. Following the tragic event, Davis's brother, Geoffrey, had decided he was going to take over the Council seat running on the Democratic platform, but on election day, November 4, Geoffrey Davis lost by a large margin to James as the Working Families Party nominee. During her 2003 race, James officially became a member of the Working Families Party, and was the first city-wide office-holder who ran solely on the WFP line. ===City Council tenure=== [[File:NLN Letitia James.jpg|thumb|200px|James speaking at [[New York City Hall|City Hall]], 2008]] James is the first member of the Working Families Party to win office in New York State, and the first [[third political party|third-party]] member to be elected to the city council since 1977.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2003/11/19/nyregion/public-lives-only-the-party-is-minor-not-its-councilwoman.html|title=Public Lives; Only the Party Is Minor, Not Its Councilwoman|publisher=New York Times|author=Richardson, Lynda|date=2003-11-19}} (She has since changed back to the Democratic party.) In 2005, James became involved in advocating against the proposed [[Brooklyn Nets Arena]] in her district, this was a case that put her against her Mayor [[Michael Bloomberg]], [[Borough President]] [[Marty Markowitz]] and developer [[Bruce Ratner]]. James opposed the use of [[eminent domain]] to evict her constituents, selling the [[Metropolitan Transportation Authority (New York)|MTA]]'s [[Atlantic Yards]] property below its [[market value]], and keeping the planning of the project away from the New York City Council. [[Bertha Lewis (activist)|Bertha Lewis]], a founder of the Working Families Party and the New York City affiliate of [[Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now]] (ACORN), on the other hand, endorsed the stadium development once Ratner accepted her plan for [[affordable housing]]. James again won the Working Families and the Democratic parties' nominations by a large margin over Samuel Eric Blackwell, an urban planner at [[Long Island University]] and pro-stadium advocate. She was re-elected on the Democratic line on November 8, 2005, with 88.11% of the vote, compared to 6.80% for [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Anthony Herbert, and 5.08% for [[Independence Party of New York|Independence Party]] candidate Charles B. Billups.{{cite web|url=http://ny1.com/ny/Election/2005election/index.html?page_name=brooklyn|title=Election 2005|publisher=[[NY1]]}} On October 10, 2006 there was a devastating fire at the [[Broken Angel House]], an architectural icon in [[Clinton Hill, Brooklyn]]. The fire attracted attention from the [[New York City Department of Buildings]], which resulted in the citation of numerous building code violations. James represented Broken Angel's owner, Arthur Wood, [[Pro bono publico|pro bono]] in his negotiations to keep his home. The agency decided to allow Wood to re-occupy Broken Angel provided the upper levels were taken down and the central stairwell reconstructed.{{cite news|url=http://www.brooklynpapers.com/html/issues/_vol30/30_01/30_01nets3.html|title='Angel' on the market: Clinton Hill amalgam is yours for $1.5 mil|publisher=[[The Brooklyn Papers]]|author=Rubinstein, Dana|date=2007-01-06}} James was the sponsor of New York law 2007/29, which addressed the Alternative Enforcement Program by the [[New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development|Department of Housing Preservation and Development]] and violations of the housing maintenance code and multiple dwelling law; and 2008/004, which addressed the availability of Child Health Plus laws in day cares. She was the first to question cost overruns and irregularities in the subcontracting work of the new CityTime payroll system much touted by Bloomberg which eventually led to several indictments, Bloomberg asking a tech giant for $600 million back, and two consultants fleeing the country in 2011.{{cite news|url=http://www.wnyc.org/story/137041-citytime-payroll-manager-fired-over-pay-scandal/|title=CityTime Payroll Manager Fired Over Pay Scandal|publisher=WNYC}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/450-million-fraud-citytime-husband-wife-team-flee-country-leaving-200-employees-lurch-article-1.130227|title=$450 million Fraud: CityTime husband and wife team flee country leaving 200 employees in the lurch|publisher=New York Daily News}} James originally advocated for the demolition of the [[Second Empire (architecture)|Second Empire]] houses on [[Admiral's Row]] in order to build a parking lot for a proposed supermarket to serve residents in nearby housing developments, but later supported preserving some of the historic housing.{{cite news|url=http://www.brooklynpaper.com/stories/31/27/31_27_mm_admirals_row.html|title=James gets in middle of 'Row'|publisher=The Brooklyn Paper|author=McLaughlin, Mike|date=2008-07-15}} In 2008, James, with [[Bill de Blasio]], advocated against Mayor [[Michael Bloomberg]]'s attempts to seek a third term without a voter referendum.{{cite news|url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/10/06/an-emerging-voice-in-term-limits-debate|title=Councilman Balks at Procedure to Change Term Limits|work=City Blogs|publisher=New York Times|author=Hicks, Jonathan P.|date=2008-10-16}} James won the Democratic [[Primary election|primary]] in September 2009 against her opponents, community organizer Delia Hunley-Adossa,[http://fort-greene.thelocal.nytimes.com/2009/09/15/james-in-a-landslide/ "James, in a landslide"]. Newman, Andy (2009-09-15) The Local who received more than $200,000 from Forest City Ratner{{cite news|url=http://fort-greene.thelocal.nytimes.com/2009/08/27/the-day-hunley-adossa-group-got-more-than-200g-from-ratner/|title=The Day: Hunley-Adossa Group Got More than 200G from Ratner|publisher=''The New York Times''}} and Medhanie Estiphanos, a financial consultant. James went on to win re-election for a second term. With New York State Senator [[Eric Adams (politician)|Eric Adams]], Congressman [[Hakeem Jeffries]], and NY city councilman [[Jumaane Williams]], James called upon Mayor Bloomberg to investigate systemic corruption in the [[NYPD]] in November 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.nysenate.gov/press-release/senator-eric-adams-assemblyman-hakeem-jeffries-councilmember-letitia-james-and-council|title=Senator Eric Adams, Assemblyman Hakeem Jeffries, Councilmember Letitia James and Councilmember Jumaane Williams call on Mayor Bloomberg to appoint Commission to Investigate Systemic Corruption in the NYPD|publisher=nysenate.gov}} She was also one of four councilmembers to sue the NYPD over its treatment of protesters at Occupy Wall Street. In May 2013, with a group that included construction unions, community groups and other elected officials, she was a part of an Article 78 lawsuit against the [[Bloomberg administration]] and Acadia Realty Trust seeking the shut-down of the City Point real estate project and a reassessment of its environmental impact.{{cite news|url=http://www.cityandstateny.com/pols-james-mosley-lend-support-to-city-point-lawsuit/|title=Pols James, Mosley Lend Support To City Point Lawsuit|publisher=''City & State''}} In June 2016, James attempted to pressure six [[financial institution]]s, including [[BB&T]], Berkshire Bank, [[Citizens Financial Group]], [[People's United Financial|People's United Bank]], [[Regions Financial Corporation]] and [[TD Bank, N.A.|TD Bank]] into ending its practice of providing [[financial services]] to gun manufacturers.{{cite news|url=http://pubadvocate.nyc.gov/news/articles/pa-james-calls-six-banks-terminate-financial-backing-sig-sauer-maker-gun-used-orlando/|title=PA James Calls on Six Banks to Terminate Financial Backing of Sig Sauer, Maker of Gun Used in Orlando Massacre|publisher=''Public Advocate for the City of New York''}} [[BB&T]] was specifically requested to drop the accounts of [[SIG Sauer]] of [[New Hampshire]], but denied the request.{{cite news|url=http://www.journalnow.com/business/business_news/local/bb-t-doesn-t-agree-to-drop-sig-sauer-firearm/article_bdee92b0-f181-5c82-afbb-624bb8d7d220.html|title=BB&T doesn’t agree to drop Sig Sauer firearm accounts|publisher=''Winston-Salem Journal''}} ===Committee assignments=== *Committee on Economic Development (chair) *Committee on Sanitation (chair) *Committee on Parks & Recreation *Committee on Small Business *Committee on Technology in Government *Committee on Veteran Affairs *Committee on Women's Issues[http://www.gothamgazette.com/article/searchlight/20100122/203/3159]. Gross, Courtney. (2010-01-22) "Stated Meeting: The Council's New Order" ===Race for NYC Public Advocate=== {{main article|New York City Public Advocate election, 2013}} In the 2013 election campaign for Public Advocate, James was endorsed by many of the city's important labor unions, [[National Organization for Women|NOW]], [[Planned Parenthood]], Democracy for NYC, [[League of Conservation Voters]], ''[[Amsterdam News]]'' and ''[[El Diario La Prensa|El Diario]].'' James accomplished her first-place finish in spite of her campaign trailing [[Daniel Squadron]]'s and [[Reshma Saujani]]'s, in fundraising.{{cite web|url=http://www.capitalnewyork.com/article/politics/2013/05/8530470/shunning-squadron-brooklyn-democratic-organization-backs-letitia-ja|title=Shunning Squadron, the Brooklyn Democratic organization backs Letitia James|publisher=Capital}} She was endorsed by third-place finisher Saujani on September 17{{cite web|url=http://www.letitiajames2013.com/reshma_saujani_endorses_letitia_james|title=Reshma Saujani endorses Letitia James|publisher=Letitia James campaign}} and subsequently won the run-off. In the general election in November 2013 she won with 83.55% of the vote (78.02% on the Democratic Party line and 5.53% on the Working Families Party line) with no Republican opponent. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://pubadvocate.nyc.gov/ Official New York City Public Advocate Website] * [http://teamtish.blogspot.com/ Letitia James' official staff blog "team tish"] * [http://www.gothamgazette.com/campaign2005/35 Gotham Gazette Campaign 2005 District 35] {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box | before=[[James E. Moore (Texas politician)|Bill Moore]] |successor1 = [[Chet Brooks (politician)|Chet Brooks]] |birth_name = Barbara Charline Jordan |birth_date = {{birth date|1936|2|21}} |birth_place = [[Houston]], [[Texas]], [[United States|U.S.]] |death_date = {{nowrap|{{death date and age|1996|1|17|1936|2|21}}}} |death_place = [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], [[Texas]], [[United States|U.S.]] |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |partner = Nancy Earl {{small|(late 1960s–1996)}} |alma_mater = [[Texas Southern University]]
[[Boston University School of Law|Boston University]] |religion = [[Baptists|Baptist]] }} '''Barbara Charline Jordan''' (February 21, 1936 – January 17, 1996) was a lawyer, educator,{{Cite book|title = Encyclopedia of African American History 1896 to the Present: From the Age of Segregation to the Twenty-First Century|last = Finkelman|first = Paul|publisher = Oxford University Press|year = 2009|isbn = 978-0-19-516779-5|location = New York|pages = 59–61}} an [[politics of the United States|American politician]], and a leader of the [[Civil Rights movement]]. A [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]], she was the first African American elected to the [[Texas Senate]] after [[Reconstruction era in the United States|Reconstruction]], the first [[Southern United States|Southern]] African-American female elected to the [[United States House of Representatives]], the first known lesbian elected to the [[United States Congress]] (though this was not known to the public during her tenure), and the first African-American woman to deliver a keynote address at a [[Democratic National Convention]]. She received the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]], among numerous other honors. She was a member of the [[Peabody Award]]s Board of Jurors from 1978 to 1980.[http://www.peabodyawards.com/stories/story/george-foster-peabody-awards-board-members The Peabody Awards - George Foster Peabody Awards Board Members] On her death, she became the first African-American woman to be buried in the [[Texas State Cemetery]].{{cite web|title=Barbara Jordan|url=http://www.humanitiestexas.org/programs/tx-originals/list/barbara-jordan|work=Humanities Texas |accessdate=18 February 2016|quote=[...] When she died, in 1996, her burial in the Texas State Cemetery marked yet another first: she was the first black woman interred there. [...]}} ==Early life== Barbara Charline Jordan was born in [[Houston]], Texas's [[Fifth Ward, Houston|Fifth Ward]].{{Wayback |date=20110716145243 |url=http://www.beejae.com/bjordan.htm |title=Barbara Jordan }} at Beejae.com Jordan's childhood centered on church life: her parents were Benjamin Jordan, a [[Baptist]] preacher; and Arlyne Patten Jordan, a teacher in the church. Jordan, the youngest of 3 girls, had two siblings, Rosemary Jordan McGowan and Bennie Jordan Creswell (d. 2000). Jordan attended Roberson Elementary School. She graduated from [[Wheatley High School (Houston)|Phillis Wheatley High School]] in 1952 with honors.{{Wayback |date=20081114152344 |url=http://www.hrc.org/issues/3554.htm |title=Profile: Barbara Jordan (1936–1996)}} at Human Rights Campaign Jordan credited a speech she heard in her high school years by [[Edith S. Sampson]] with inspiring her to become a lawyer.{{cite journal|last=Ross|first=Irwin|title=Barbara Jordan-New Voice in Washington|journal=The Reader's Digest|date=February 1977|pages=148–152}} Because of segregation, she did not attend [[University of Texas at Austin|The University of Texas at Austin]] and instead chose [[Texas Southern University]], majoring in [[political science]] and history. Jordan was a national champion [[debate]]r, defeating opponents from Yale and Brown and tying Harvard University. She graduated ''[[magna cum laude]]'' in 1956. At Texas Southern University, she pledged [[Delta Sigma Theta]] sorority. She attended [[Boston University School of Law]], graduating in 1959. ==Career== Jordan taught political science at [[Tuskegee Institute]] in [[Alabama]] for a year. In 1960, she returned to Houston, passed the [[bar examination|bar]] and started a private law practice. Jordan campaigned unsuccessfully in 1962 and 1964 for the [[Texas House of Representatives]].{{cite web |url=http://www.planetout.com/news/history/aahist/jordan.html |title=Stateswoman Barbara Jordan – A Closeted Lesbian |publisher=Planet Out |accessdate=July 12, 2007 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071214015046/http://www.planetout.com/news/history/aahist/jordan.html |archivedate=December 14, 2007}} She won a seat in the [[Texas Senate]] in 1966, becoming the first African-American state senator since 1883 and the first black woman to serve in that body. Re-elected to a full term in the Texas Senate in 1968, she served until 1972. She was the first African-American female to serve as president ''[[pro tem]]'' of the state senate and served one day, June 10, 1972, as [[List of Governors of Texas#Acting Governors of Texas|acting governor of Texas]]. To date Jordan is the only African-American woman to serve as governor of a state (excluding lieutenant governors).Barbara Jordan Papers, Special Collections, Texas Southern University, October 15, 2015. During her time in the Texas Legislature, Jordan sponsored or cosponsored some 70 bills. In 1972, she was elected to Congress, the first woman to represent Texas in the House in her own right. She received extensive support from former [[President of the United States|President]] [[Lyndon B. Johnson]], who helped her secure a position on the [[United States House Committee on the Judiciary|House Judiciary Committee]]. In 1974, she made an influential televised speech before the House Judiciary Committee supporting the process of [[impeachment]] of [[Richard Nixon]], Johnson's successor as President.{{cite news|title=Barbara C. Jordan|url=http://www.history.com/topics/black-history/barbara-c-jordan|accessdate=7 May 2015|publisher=History.com|date=2009}} In 1975, she was appointed by [[Carl Albert]], then [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives]], to the [[Democratic Steering and Policy Committee]]. In 1976, Jordan, mentioned as a possible running mate to [[Jimmy Carter]] of [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], became instead the first African-American woman to deliver a keynote address at the [[1976 Democratic National Convention|Democratic National Convention]]. Despite not being a candidate, Jordan received one delegate vote (0.03%) for President at the [[1976 Democratic National Convention|Convention]].{{cite web|title=Our Campaigns - US President - D Convention Race - Jul 12, 1976|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=58483|accessdate=4 July 2015}} Jordan retired from politics in 1979 and became an adjunct professor teaching ethics at the [[University of Texas at Austin]] Lyndon B. Johnson School of Public Affairs. She again was a keynote speaker at the Democratic National Convention in 1992. [[File:Jordan and Carter ca. 1977 w ccwatermark.jpg|thumb|Jordan and President Carter, ca. 1977. Photo by Dev O'Neill.]] In 1994 and until her death in 1996, Jordan chaired the U.S. Commission on Immigration Reform, which advocated [[immigration reduction|increased restriction of immigration]], increased penalties on employers that violated US immigration regulations.{{cite web|url=http://www.utexas.edu/lbj/uscir/022495.html |title=The U.S. Commission on Immigration Reform |publisher=Utexas.edu |accessdate=November 27, 2010}}Cassidy, Peter. "We have your number: the push for a national ID card." ''[[The Progressive]]'', December 1, 1994. However that is at odds to what the Jordan Commission says its report recommended, "Unfortunately, they have also been misrepresented as a national ID card. What the Commission has recommended is a measured approach to the development of a new system for verifying that individuals are authorized to work in the United States-that is all" (Jordan testimony before Congress on Sept 29, 1994). "The U.S. Commission on Immigration Reform, headed by widely respected former Texas Congresswoman Barbara Jordan, turned in its long-awaited recommendations in September, and among them was one that could severely curb traditional American freedoms," according to open border supporters. Clinton endorsed the Jordan Commission's proposals. President Clinton said the proposals “reflect a balanced immigration policy that makes the most of our diversity while protecting the American work force so that we can better compete in the emerging global economy.” https://www.utexas.edu/lbj/uscir/092994.htmlPear, Robert. "[http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=990CE5D7103EF93BA35755C0A963958260 Clinton Embraces a Proposal to Cut Immigration by a Third]." ''The New York Times''. Accessed May 13, 2008. While she was Chair of the U.S. Commission on Immigration Reform she argued that "it is both a right and a responsibility of a democratic society to manage immigration so that it serves the national interest." Opponents of modern U.S. immigration policy have cited her willingness to penalize employers who violate U.S. immigration regulations, tighten border security, oppose amnesty for illegal immigrants, harm to US citizens in jobs and employment from cheaper illegal alien workers,{{citation needed|date=October 2011}}, and clear process for the deportation of legal immigrants.{{cite web| url=http://www.utexas.edu/lbj/uscir/022495.html |title=Testimony of Barbara Jordan, February 24, 1995 |publisher=Utexas.edu |accessdate=November 27, 2010}} In 1994, Clinton awarded her the Presidential Medal of Freedom and The NAACP presented her with the Springarn Medal. She was honored many times and was given over 20 honorary degrees from institutions across the country, including Harvard and Princeton, and was elected to the Texas and National Women's Halls of Fame. ===Statement on the Articles of Impeachment=== On July 25, 1974, Texas [[United States House of Representatives|Representative]] Barbara Jordan delivered a 15-minute televised speech in front of the members of the [[U.S. House Judiciary Committee]].[http://www.history.com/topics/barbara-c-jordan "Barbara C. Jordan Profile"], The History Channel, A&E Television Networks, LLC. 1996-2013. Accessed October 5, 2013. She presented the opening speech for former President [[Richard Nixon]]’s impeachment hearings. This speech is thought to be one of the best speeches of the 20th century.[http://www.americanrhetoric.com/top100speechesall.html "American Rhetoric: Top 100 Speeches"], American Rhetoric Website, 2001-2013. Accessed 5 October 2013. Throughout her speech, Jordan strongly stood by the [[Constitution of the United States of America]]. She defended the [[checks and balances]] system, which was set in place to inhibit any politician from abusing their power. Jordan never flat out said that she wanted Nixon impeached, but rather subtly and cleverly implied her thoughts.[http://www.newmanrhetoric.blogspot.com "Mr. Newman's Digital Rhetorical Symposium: Barbara Jordan: Statement on the Articles of Impeachment], Newman Rhetoric Blogging Website, 2010. Accessed 5 October 2013. She simply stated facts that proved Nixon to be untrustworthy and heavily involved in illegal situations. She protested that the [[Watergate scandal]] will forever ruin the trust American citizens have for their government. One of the reasons Nixon resigned over the Watergate scandal was because of this speech. This powerful and influential statement earned Jordan national praise for her rhetoric, morals, and wisdom. ===Legislation=== Jordan supported the [[Community Reinvestment Act]] of 1977, legislation that required banks to lend and make services available to underserved poor and minority communities. She supported the renewal of the [[Voting Rights Act of 1965]] and expansion of that act to cover language minorities; this extended protection to Hispanics in Texas and was opposed by Texas Governor [[Dolph Briscoe]] and Secretary of State [[Mark White]]. She also authored an act that ended federal authorization of price fixing by manufacturers. During Jordan's tenure as a Congresswoman she sponsored or cosponsored over 300 bills or resolutions, several of which are still in effect today as law. ==Personal life== Jordan's partner of approximately thirty years was Nancy Earl, an educational psychologist, whom she met on a camping trip in the late 1960s. Earl acted as an occasional speech writer for Jordan, and later as a caregiver when Jordan began to suffer from multiple sclerosis in 1973. In the KUT radio documentary ''Rediscovering Barbara Jordan'', [[President of the United States|President]] [[Bill Clinton]] stated that he wanted to nominate Jordan for the [[United States Supreme Court]], but by the time he could do so, Jordan's health problems prevented him from nominating her.[http://www.kut.org/items/show/5525 Transcript of ''Rediscovering Barbara Jordan''], KUT.org, February 8, 2006. Retrieved November 4, 2006. Jordan later also suffered from [[leukemia]]. In 1988, Jordan nearly drowned in her backyard swimming pool while performing physical therapy, but she was saved by Earl who found her floating in the pool and revived her.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1988/07/31/us/barbara-jordan-is-hospitalized.html|title=Barbara Jordan is hospitalized|publisher=nytimes.com|accessdate=March 7, 2015}} Jordan died at the age of 59 due to complications from pneumonia on January 17, 1996, in Austin, Texas.{{cite news|url = http://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/18/us/barbara-jordan-dies-at-59-her-voice-stirred-the-nation.html|title = Barbara Jordan dies at 59|publisher = nytimes.com|accessdate = March 7, 2015}} ==Recognition and legacy== * 1984: Inducted into the [[Texas Women's Hall of Fame]]. * 1990: Inducted into the [[National Women's Hall of Fame]] * 1992: The [[Spingarn Medal]] from the [[NAACP]].{{cite web|url=http://www.naacp.org/pages/spingarn-medal-winners|title=NAACP Spingarn Medal|accessdate=November 29, 2014}} * 1993: The [[Elizabeth Blackwell]] Award from [[Hobart and William Smith Colleges]]. * 1994: The [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]]. * 1995: The second ever female awardee of the [[United States Military Academy]]'s [[Sylvanus Thayer Award]].{{cite web|url=http://www.blackpast.org/1995-barbara-jordan-s-acceptance-speech-sylvanus-thayer-award-united-states-military-academy-west-po|title=Barbara Jordan Sylvanus Thayer Award|accessdate=March 7, 2015}} Her 1974 statement on the articles of impeachment (regarding President [[Richard Nixon]]) was listed as #13 in American Rhetoric's Top 100 Speeches of the 20th Century (listed by rank).{{cite web|author=Michael E. Eidenmuller |url=http://www.americanrhetoric.com/top100speechesall.html |title=Top 100 Speeches of the 20th Century by Rank |publisher=American Rhetoric |date=2009-02-13 |accessdate=2015-10-27}}{{cite web|author=Michael E. Eidenmuller |url=http://www.americanrhetoric.com/speeches/barbarajordanjudiciarystatement.htm |title=Barbara Jordan - Statement on House Judiciary Proceedings to Impeach President Richard Nixon |publisher=American Rhetoric |date=1974-07-25 |accessdate=2015-10-27}} Her 1976 DNC keynote address was listed as #5 in American Rhetoric's Top 100 Speeches of the 20th Century (listed by rank). ===Namesakes in Texas=== The main terminal at [[Austin-Bergstrom International Airport]] is named after Jordan, as well as a boulevard in central Austin. Several schools bear Jordan's name, including an elementary school in [[Odessa, Texas]], and [[Austin, Texas]], [https://archive.austinisd.org/schools/details.phtml?id=073 Barbara Jordan Early College Prep School], a middle school in [[Cibolo, Texas]], and [[Barbara Jordan High School]] in Houston. The Kaiser Family Foundation currently operates the [[Barbara Jordan Health Policy Scholars]], a fellowship designed for people of color who are college juniors, seniors, and recent graduates as a summer experience working in a congressional office. ===Other honors=== In 2000, the [http://jrcla.org/ Jordan/Rustin Coalition] (JRC) was created in Jordan's honor. The organization mobilized gay and lesbian African Americans to aid in the passage of marriage equality in the state of California. Along with [[Bayard Rustin]], a civil rights leader and close confidante of [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]], Barbara Jordan is remembered for her advocacy of progressive politics. According to its website, "the mission [of the JRC] is to empower Black same-gender loving, lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender individuals and families in Greater Los Angeles, to promote equal marriage rights and to advocate for fair treatment of everyone without regard to race, sexual orientation, gender identity, or gender expression." On March 27, 2000, a play based on Jordan's life premiered at the Victory Garden Theater in Chicago, Illinois.{{cite book |last= Thatcher |first= Kristine |title= Voice of Good Hope |publisher= Dramatists Play Service, Inc. |year= 2004 |isbn= 0-8222-1960-3}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=-TweB6n_Q0wC&pg=PA4&lpg=PP1&output=html Titled], "Voice of Good Hope", [[Kristine Thatcher]]'s biographical evocation of Jordan's life played in theaters from San Francisco to New York.Siegel, Naomi. "[http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9806E6D71439F937A15752C1A9649C8B63 THEATER REVIEW; She Had a Voice That Resonates Still]", ''The New York Times'', November 24, 2002. Retrieved November 20, 2008. On April 24, 2009, a Barbara Jordan statue was unveiled at the University of Texas at Austin, where Jordan taught at the time of her death. The Barbara Jordan statue campaign was paid for by a student fee increase approved by the University of Texas Board of Regents. The effort was originally spearheaded by the 2002–2003 Tappee class of the Texas Orange Jackets, the "oldest women's organization at the University" (of Texas at Austin).{{cite web|last=Sanders |first=Joshunda |url=http://www.statesman.com/news/content/news/stories/local/04/20/0420jordan.html |title=Jordan's statue to grace UT campus: Dedication of Barbara Jordan statue on Friday will include a weeklong celebration |publisher=Statesman.com |date=April 20, 2009 |accessdate=November 27, 2010}} In 2011, actor/playwright [[Jade Esteban Estrada]] portrayed Jordan in the solo musical comedy ''ICONS: The Lesbian and Gay History of the World, Vol. 5'' which includes the song "Nancy's Eyes" sung by the character of Jordan with music and lyrics by Estrada. In 2011, the Barbara Jordan [[Forever Stamp]] was issued. It is the 34th stamp in the Black Heritage series of U.S. stamps.{{cite web|url=http://abclocal.go.com/ktrk/story?section=news/local&id=8356990|title=Stamp honors political trailblazer Barbara Jordan|work=ABC13 Houston|accessdate=November 29, 2014}} In 2012, Jordan was inducted into the [[Legacy Walk]], an outdoor public display which celebrates [[LGBT]] history and people.{{cite web|url=http://www.legacyprojectchicago.org/2012_INDUCTEES.html|title=2012 INDUCTEES|author=Victor Salvo // The Legacy Project|accessdate=November 29, 2014}} The Barbara Jordan Media Awards are given annually to media professionals and students who "have produced material for the public which accurately and positively reports on individuals with disabilities, using People First language and respectful depictions."[http://gov.texas.gov/disabilities/awards/barbara_jordan_media_awards/ Office of the Governor - Greg Abbott: Committee on People with Disabilities - Barbara Jordan Media Awards] There is also the Barbara Jordan Public-Private Leadership Award.[http://forwardtimesonline.com/2013/index.php/national-news/item/2707-the-honorable-hillary-rodham-clinton-receives-barbara-jordan-public-private-leadership-award The Honorable Hillary Rodham Jerry Ellis (divorced)
Israel Tookes (divorced) | children = 6 | website =[http://www.africanamericanoutreach.com Official website] }} '''Alveda Celeste King''' (born January 22, 1951) is an American activist, author and former state representative for the 28th District in the Georgia House of Representatives. She is a niece of [[civil rights]] leader [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]] and daughter of [[civil rights]] activist Rev. [[A. D. King]] and his wife Naomi Barber King. She is a [[Fox News Channel]] contributor. She once served as a Senior Fellow at the [[Alexis de Tocqueville Institution]], a conservative Washington, D.C. [[think-tank]]. She is a former member of the [[Georgia House of Representatives]] and the founder of Alveda King Ministries. ==Childhood and family== Alveda King was born in [[Atlanta, Georgia]]. She was the first of five children of [[A. D. King]]—the younger brother of [[Martin Luther King Jr.]]—and Naomi Barber King. King says her mother wanted to abort her so she could continue college, but her grandfather was able to convince her to keep her child.{{cite video|people=Alveda King|date=January 22, 2008|title=Alveda King talking about abortion|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JzTsrMTmRcY|location=In front of the Supreme Court building|time=04:40|accessdate=October 5, 2010}} When she was 12, her father became a leader of the [[Birmingham campaign]] while serving as pastor at the First Baptist Church of Ensley in [[Birmingham, Alabama]]. Later that same year, King's house was bombed by opponents to the civil rights movement. ==Father's death== In 1969, her father, A.D. King, was found dead in the pool at his home.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/05/opinion/05branch.html|title=Dr. King's Newest Marcher|author=[[Taylor Branch]]|quote=in fact A. D. King drowned at home after a long bout with alcohol and depression. – Taylor Branch,author of the Pulitzer prize-winning biography of Martin Luther King|newspaper=New York Times|date=September 4, 2010|accessdate=September 9, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100908120105/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/05/opinion/05branch.html| archivedate= September 8, 2010 | deadurl= no}} The cause of death was listed as an accidental drowning.{{cite news|title=The Rev. A. D. Williams King|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,901197,00.html|work=Time|date=August 1, 1969|accessdate=November 1, 2007}}{{cite news|title=Bomb Hits Home in Birmingham|work=New York Times |url=http://mlk-kpp01.stanford.edu/index.php/encyclopedia/encyclopedia/enc_king_alfred_daniel_williams_1930_1969|date=August 1, 1963|accessdate=November 1, 2007}}{{cite journal|title=Introduction in Papers|work=Introduction in Papers|volume=1|issue=26|page=43}}{{cite news|title=A Rights Activist|work=Thomas A. Johnson, New York Times|date=July 22, 1969}} Grandfather King said in his autobiography, "Alveda had been up the night before, she said, talking with her father and watching a television movie with him. He'd seemed unusually quiet...and not very interested in the film. But he had wanted to stay up and Alveda left him sitting in an easy chair, staring at the TV, when she went off to bed... I had questions about A.D.'s death and I still have them now. He was a good swimmer. Why did he drown? I don't know – I don't know that we will ever know what happened."{{cite book|title=Daddy King An Autobiography|authorlink=Martin Luther King, Sr.|last1=King|first1=Martin Luther, Sr.|first2= Clayton|last2=Riley|year=1980|publisher=Morrow|isbn=978-0-688-03699-7|page=192}} ==Abortions== King had two abortions and attempted to get a third one. Her doctor did the first abortion without her family’s knowledge.{{cite web|title=Niece of Dr. Martin Luther King speaks out for the future of the yet unborn. How can the "Dream" survive if we murder our children?|url=http://www.priestsforlife.org/africanamerican/naacp-presentation.htm|website=African American Outreach|ref=18}} When she was pregnant in 1973, she went to [[Planned Parenthood]] and got a second abortion.{{cite video|people=Alveda King|date= January 22, 2008|title=Alveda King talking about abortion|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JzTsrMTmRcY|location=In front of the Supreme Court building|time=03:51|accessdate=October 5, 2010}} She was divorced soon after that. Later, she wanted to get a third abortion, but neither the father nor her grandfather agreed with her.{{cite video|people=Alveda King|date=January 22, 2008|title=Alveda King talking about abortion|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JzTsrMTmRcY|location=In front of the Supreme Court building|time=03:51|accessdate=October 5, 2010}} ==Education== King studied journalism{{cite journal|title='He Never Gives Us More Than We Can Bear'|author=Hamilton Bims|journal=Ebony|year=1974|volume=29|issue=12|page=38|issn=0012-9011|publisher=Johnson Publishing Company|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JN4DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA38}} and sociology as an undergraduate, and she received a [[Master of Arts]] degree in business management from [[Central Michigan University]]. She received an [[honorary doctorate]] from [[Saint Anselm College]].{{cite web|title=Dr. Alveda C. King|url=http://www.priestsforlife.org/staff/alvedaking.htm|publisher=Priests for Life|accessdate=August 27, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100830193318/http://www.priestsforlife.org/staff/alvedaking.htm|archivedate=August 30, 2010|deadurl=no}} ==Public office== From 1979-83, King represented the 28th District in the [[Georgia House of Representatives]].{{citation|url=http://neptune3.galib.uga.edu/ssp/cgi-bin/legis-idx.pl?sessionid=7f000001&type=backdiv&byte=401428692|title=Acts and Resolutions of the General Assembly of the State of Georgia|year=1979|volume=1|page=2059}} The district included [[Fulton County, Georgia|Fulton County]],{{cite web|title=Women in the Georgia House of Representatives, 1923 – 2000|url=http://sos.georgia.gov/archives/what_do_we_have/wghr.htm|publisher=Georgia Secretary of State|accessdate=August 27, 2010}} and King served as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]].{{cite web|last=Denvir|first=Daniel|title=Meet MLK's Glenn Beck-loving niece|url=http://www.salon.com/news/politics/war_room/2010/08/27/alveda_king_glenn_beck/index.html|work=Salon|accessdate=August 27, 2010|date=August 27, 2010| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100830200941/http://www.salon.com/news/politics/war_room/2010/08/27/alveda_king_glenn_beck/index.html| archivedate= August 30, 2010|deadurl=no}} In 1984, Alveda King ran for the seat of [[Georgia's 5th congressional district]] in the [[United States House of Representatives]] and supported the Rev. [[Jesse Jackson]] for [[Jesse Jackson presidential campaign, 1984|president]].{{citation|title=Alveda King Beal Seeks A Congressional Seat, Supports Jesse Jackson|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bbQDAAAAMBAJ|work=Jet|date=April 23, 1984|page=13|volume=66|number=7}} The 5th Congressional seat, at the time of King's campaign was held by [[Wyche Fowler]]. [[Andrew Young]], who held the seat prior to Fowler, endorsed [[Hosea Williams]], one of Martin Luther King, Jr.'s most trusted lieutenants and perhaps best known for organizing and leading the first Selma March.{{cite web|publisher=National Park Service|work=Martin Luther King, Jr National Historic Site|title=Reverend Hosea Williams|url=http://www.nps.gov/features/malu/feat0002/wof/Hosea_Williams.htm|accessdate=May 16, 2012}} Coretta Scott King did not endorse her niece. Young, who had given up the seat to serve as [[United States Ambassador to the United Nations|U.S. Ambassador to the UN]], and Williams approached King and asked her to end her campaign for the seat so that she could dedicate more time to her family. Young later apologized for what he called "some blatantly chauvinistic remarks."{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=Campaign Notes; 'Chauvinistic Remarks' Conceded by Young|date=July 12, 1984|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/12/us/campaign-notes-chauvinistic-remarks-conceded-by-young.html|work=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=August 29, 2010|quote=The Mayor also conceded that when Mrs. Beal said she objected to his "chauvinistic attitude," he had told her that her uncle, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., and her father, the Rev. Alfred King, were "male chauvinist pigs, too."}} She did not withdraw. With the black vote split, Fowler defeated both King and Williams in the primary. That was the last time she ran for elective office. However, since then, she has publicly stated that she is a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]].[http://www.priestsforlife.org/africanamerican/blog/index.php/when-i-was-a-democrat When I was a Democrat]: "I've been a Democrat, and I've been a Republican. I've even considered being an independent. Today, I'm just a Christian." ==Pro-life activism== King has been a [[pro-life]] speaker since 1983 and often speaks on college campuses about abortion issues.{{cite web|url=http://www.speroforum.com/a/17811/Dr-Alveda-King-featured-speaker-at-prolife-rally|title=Dr. Alveda King featured speaker at pro-life rally|publisher=Speroforum.com|accessdate=September 5, 2010}} She joined the pro-life movement, pushing to offer women [[alternatives to abortion]].{{cite web|last=Jacob|first=Jennifer|url=http://www.meridianstar.com/local/local_story_304013404.html|title=Alveda King visits Meridian with pro-life message|publisher=Meridian Star|date=October 31, 2009|accessdate=August 28, 2010}} Angela D. Dillard classifies King as among "prominent black members of the Religious Right".{{cite book|last=Dillard|first=Angela D.|title=Guess Who's Coming to Dinner Now?: Multicultural Conservatism in America|year=2002|place=New York City|publisher=NYU Press|isbn=0-8147-1940-6|page=164|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rjSIev7NEMUC}} ==''Restoring Honor'' rally== On August 28, 2010, King spoke at [[Glenn Beck's "Restoring Honor" rally]] at the [[Lincoln Memorial]].{{cite web|last=MacAskill|first=Ewen|title=US right claims spirit of Martin Luther King at Lincoln Memorial rally|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/aug/28/us-right-king-lincoln-memorial|work=The Guardian|accessdate=August 29, 2010|date=August 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100829173330/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/aug/28/us-right-king-lincoln-memorial|archivedate=August 29, 2010|deadurl=no}} Before the rally King explained to the ''[[Christian Science Monitor]]'' that speaking at the rally was a chance to engage in freedom of speech and to praise the man, [[Abraham Lincoln|Lincoln]], that "led this fledgling nation out of slavery, and made my people free."{{cite news|first=Alveda|last=King|title=Glenn Beck 8/28 rally: It's a matter of honor|date=August 26, 2010|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/Commentary/Opinion/2010/0826/Glenn-Beck-8-28-rally-It-s-a-matter-of-honor|work=[[Christian Science Monitor]]|accessdate=August 29, 2010|quote=If we want to sing the national anthem at a memorial to the man who led this fledgling nation out of slavery, and made my people free, we should be able to send our voices soaring to the heavens. Glenn Beck's "Rally to Restore Honor" this Saturday will give us that chance, and that's why I feel it's important for me to be there.|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100829044304/http://www.csmonitor.com/Commentary/Opinion/2010/0826/Glenn-Beck-8-28-rally-It-s-a-matter-of-honor|archivedate=August 29, 2010|deadurl=no}} web|last=Dolak|first=Kevin|title=Alveda King Speaks at Glenn Beck's DC Rally|url=http://abcnews.go.com/print?id=11504453|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=August 29, 2010|date=August 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100904194941/http://abcnews.go.com/print?id=11504453|archivedate=September 4, 2010|deadurl=no}} ==Herman Cain support== King was a supporter of [[Herman Cain]] for President and defended him from sexual harassment claims, saying, "A woman knows a skirt-chaser" and "Herman Cain is no skirt-chaser."{{cite web|title=Cain supporter insists ‘Herman Cain is Report|url=http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2011/12/02/herman-cain-gets-women-to-counter-sex-harassment-claims|accessdate=October 26, 2015}} ==Claims== ===Abortion=== Alveda King has said, "Mrs. 1966.{{cite web|last=Cassandra|first=Adam|title=Dr. Alveda King: 'Coretta Scott King Knew That Her Husband Was Pro-Life'|url=http://cnsnews.com/news/article/71648|work=CNSNews.com|accessdate=August 28, 2010|date=August 27, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100828203051/http://www.cnsnews.com/news/article/71648|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=no}}{{cite web|title=Martin Luther (although she had served on the Board of Advocates of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America).{{cite news|last=Levithan|first=Kristen|title=Happy 100th Birthday, Revolutionary Rosa Parks|url=http://msmagazine.com/blog/2013/02/04/happy-100th-birthday-revolutionary-rosa-parks/|accessdate=June 23, 2013|newspaper=[[Ms. Magazine]]|date=November 24, 2015}}{{cite web|title=Rosa Parks biography|url=http://www.biography.com/people/rosa-parks-9433715?page=4|publisher=[[The Biography Channel]]|accessdate=November 24, 2015}} Alveda King once wrote: "Margaret Sanger, founder of Planned Parenthood once said, 'Colored people are like human weeds and are to be exterminated'."{{cite web|title=Eugenics and Planned Parenthood|url=http://www.priestsforlife.org/africanamerican/blog/index.php/eugenics-and-planned-parenthood|website=Priests for Life|publisher=Priests for Life}} ===LGBT rights=== King has spoken out against same-sex marriage. {{nowrap|[[University of California, Berkeley School of Social Welfare|University of California, Berkeley]]}} }} '''Barbara Jean Lee''' (born July 16, 1946) is the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] for {{ushr|CA|13}}, serving [[East Bay (San Francisco Bay Area)|East Bay]] voters from 1998 to 2013 during a time when the region was designated {{ushr|CA|9}}. She is a member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]]. She was the first woman to represent the 9th district and is also the first woman to represent the 13th district. Lee was the Chair of the [[Congressional Black Caucus]] and was the Co-Chair of the [[Congressional Progressive Caucus]]. Lee is notable as the only member of either house of Congress to vote against the [[Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Terrorists|authorization of use of force]] following the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]].[http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2001/roll342.xml Final Vote Results for Roll Call 342], ''U.S. House of Representatives''. Accessed 7 April 2007. This made her a hero among many in the [[anti-war movement]].{{cite press release |title=Conyers Denounces Death Threats Against Rep. Barbara Lee |publisher=Office of Representative John Conyers, Jr., United States House of Representatives |date=2001-09-19 |url=http://www.house.gov/conyers/pr092001.htm |accessdate=2008-03-05 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080302082718/http://www.house.gov/conyers/pr092001.htm| archivedate= 2 March 2008 | deadurl= no}} Lee has been a vocal critic of the [[war in Iraq]] and supports legislation creating a [[Department of Peace]]. ==Early life and education== Lee was born '''Barbara Jean Tutt''' in [[El Paso, Texas]], the daughter of Mildred Adaire (née Parish) and Garvin Alexander Tutt, a Lieutenant Colonel.{{cite web|title=Barbara Lee|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~battle/reps/leebarbara.htm|website=Ancestry|accessdate=1 October 2014}} According to a DNA analysis, she descends primarily from the people of [[Guinea-Bissau]] and [[Sierra Leone]].{{cite web|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2008/11/prweb1673564.htm|title=Growing Interest in DNA-Based Genetic Testing Among African American with Historic Election of President Elect Barack Obama|date=27 November 2008|work=PRWeb|accessdate=11 December 2014}}{{YouTube|8SSC1rS6B8E|Congresswoman Barbara Lee Ancestry Reveal}} She moved from [[Texas]] to [[California]] in 1960 with her military family parents, and attended [[San Fernando High School]] in [[Pacoima, Los Angeles|Pacoima, California]].{{Cite web | first= | last=Interview Transcript | url=http://www.pbs.org/wnet/tavissmiley/archive/200811/20081113_lee.html | title=Rep. Barbara Lee | work=[[The Tavis Smiley Show]] | date=November 13, 2008 | accessdate=February 28, 2011}} She was a young single mother of two receiving public assistance when she began attending college.{{cite web|url=http://www.ebdailynews.com/article/2006-11-16-bil-paul|title=ebdailynews.com|author=Sedo GmbH|publisher=Ebdailynews.com|accessdate=11 December 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2001/09/26/MN199337.DTL|title=PROFILE / Barbara Lee / Rep. Lee, committed to ideals, takes heat for vote against Bush|work=SFGate|accessdate=11 December 2014}} Lee was educated at [[Mills College]], and received an [[Master of Social Work|MSW]] from the [[University of California, Berkeley]], in 1975. ==Political career== While a student at Mills College, she was a volunteer at the Oakland chapter of the [[Black Panther Party]]'s Community Learning Center and worked on Panther co-founder [[Bobby Seale]]'s 1973 Oakland mayoral campaign.{{cite web|url=http://www.mindfully.org/Reform/2006/Black-Panthers-Led8oct06.htm|title=A Legacy of Activism: Behind Fury, Black Panthers Laid Course for Social Programs WILLIAM BRAND & CECILY BURT / Oakland Tribune 8oct2006|publisher=Mindfully.org|accessdate=11 December 2014}} Lee was a staff member for United States Representative [[Ron Dellums]] and a member of the [[California State Assembly]] and the [[California State Senate]] before entering the House. She ran for Congress in a [[special election]] that created a year-long series of five special elections as various East Bay politicians vied for political office. (For a detailed account of these elections, see [[Special election musical chairs]].) ===AUMF opposition=== Lee gained national attention in 2001 as the only member of congress to vote "No" on the [[Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Terrorists]] (AUMF), stating that she voted no not because she opposed military action but because she believed the AUMF, as written, granted overly-broad powers to wage war to the president at a time when the facts regarding the situation were not yet clear. She "warned her colleagues to be 'careful not to embark on an open-ended war with neither an exit strategy nor a focused target.'"Polner, Murray (2010-03-01) [http://www.amconmag.com/article/2010/mar/01/00032/ Left Behind], ''[[The American Conservative]]'' Lee explained, "It was a blank check to the president to attack anyone involved in the September 11 events—anywhere, in any country, without regard to our nation's long-term foreign policy, economic and national security interests, and without time limit. In granting these overly broad powers, the Congress failed its responsibility to understand the dimensions of its declaration.... The president has the constitutional authority to protect the nation from further attack, and he has mobilized the armed forces to do just that. The Congress should have waited for the facts to be presented and then acted with fuller knowledge of the consequences of our action." This vote made nationwide news reports and brought about a large and extremely polarized response, with the volume of calls gridlocking the switchboard of her Capitol Hill office. Although it appears to have reflected the beliefs of the majority of her constituents, the majority of responses from elsewhere in the nation were angry and hostile, some referring to her as "communist" and "traitor". Many of the responses included death threats against her or her family to the point that the Capitol Police provided round-the-clock plainclothes bodyguards.{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2001/09/23/INLEE.DTL|title=Why I opposed the resolution to authorize force|work=SFGate|accessdate=11 December 2014}} She was also criticized by politicians and in editorial pages of conservative-leaning newspapers, e.g. [[John Fund]]'s column in ''[[The Wall Street Journal]].''{{cite web|url=http://www.opinionjournal.com/diary/?id=95001156|title=Opinion, Editorials, Columns, Op-Ed, Letters to the Editor, Commentary - Wall Street Journal - Wsj.com|publisher=Opinionjournal.com|accessdate=11 December 2014}} She was awarded the Seán MacBride Peace Prize by the [[International Peace Bureau]] in 2002 for that vote. In her speech, she quoted the Rev. Nathan Baxter, dean of National Cathedral: “As we act, let us not become the evil that we deplore. {{cite web|url=http://www.democracynow.org/2009/9/16/let_us_not_become_the_evil_we_deplore|title="Let Us Not Become the Evil We Deplore." By Amy Goodman|work=Democracy Now!|accessdate=28 August 2016}} ===Other positions=== ;Congressional Black Caucus [[File:Obama signs Ryan White extension.jpg|thumb|left|Barbara Lee meets with [[Barack Obama]]]]She hinted to the ''[[Oakland Tribune]]'' that she would run for the leadership of the Congressional Black Caucus in September 2008, following the end of her four-year term as co-chair of the [[Congressional Progressive Caucus]].{{cite web|url=http://www.insidebayarea.com/oaklandtribune/localnews/ci_10559606|title=Barbara Lee makes move for Black Caucus chair|work=InsideBayArea.com|accessdate=11 December 2014}} ;Death penalty [[File:STS-129 Crew Meets With Members of Congress.jpg|thumb|Barbara Lee meets with [[NASA]] Administrator [[Charles Bolden]] and the [[STS-129]] [[space shuttle]] crew]]Lee's opposition to the death penalty was recognized in 2002 by [[Death Penalty Focus]], when they presented her with the [[Mario Cuomo]] Act of Courage Award.{{cite web|url=http://0-www.gpo.gov.library.colby.edu/fdsys/pkg/CREC-2003-06-26/pdf/CREC-2003-06-26-pt1-PgE1360.pdf|title=Colby College|work=Colby College|accessdate=11 December 2014}} ;Foreign affairs Although Lee is considered a [[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberal]] Democrat, she has occasionally split with members of her own party throughout her congressional career, especially on foreign policy matters. She voted in favor of limiting military operations in the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, against authorizing air strikes, and in favor of a Republican-backed plan to completely withdraw U.S. troops from the operation, all in 1999.{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/1999/roll100.xml|title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 100|publisher=Clerk.house.gov|accessdate=11 December 2014}} Lee voted against the [[Iraq War]] [[Iraq Resolution|Resolution]] in 2002.{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2002/roll455.xml|title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 455|publisher=Clerk.house.gov|accessdate=11 December 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/1999/roll103.xml|title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 103|publisher=Clerk.house.gov|accessdate=11 December 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/1999/roll101.xml|title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 101|publisher=Clerk.house.gov|accessdate=11 December 2014}} Lee was one of only 46 Democrats to vote for the Online Freedom of Speech Act of 2005.{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2005/roll559.xml|title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 559|publisher=Clerk.house.gov|accessdate=11 December 2014}} Lee was one of only 13 Democrats to vote against an emergency supplemental appropriations bill in 2007 which, among other things, funded the war in Iraq but required withdrawal of U.S. forces to begin by October 1.{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2007/roll265.xml|title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 265|publisher=Clerk.house.gov|accessdate=11 December 2014}} However, Lee voted in favor of overriding [[George W. Bush|President Bush]]'s veto of the measure on May 2.{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2007/roll276.xml|title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 276|publisher=Clerk.house.gov|accessdate=11 December 2014}} On November, 2009 Lee was one of 36 representatives to vote "nay" on [[United Nations Fact Finding Mission on the Gaza Conflict#House of Representatives resolution|House Resolution 867]], which condemned the UN's [[Goldstone Report]].{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2009/roll838.xml|title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 838|publisher=Clerk.house.gov|accessdate=11 December 2014}} Lee voted to withdraw troops from Afghanistan in 2010 and 2011.{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2010/roll098.xml|title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 98|publisher=Clerk.house.gov|accessdate=11 December 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2011/roll193.xml|title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 193|publisher=Clerk.house.gov|accessdate=11 December 2014}} Lee also voted in favor of similar resolutions involving troop withdrawal from Pakistan and, most recently, Libya.{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2010/roll473.xml|title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 473|publisher=Clerk.house.gov|accessdate=11 December 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2011/roll412.xml|title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 412|publisher=Clerk.house.gov|accessdate=11 December 2014}} Lee also joined her Republican colleagues, one of 70 Democrats to do so, in voting against a resolution to authorize limited use of force in Libya.{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2011/roll493.xml|title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 493|publisher=Clerk.house.gov|accessdate=11 December 2014}} Lee was also one of only 36 494|publisher=Clerk.house.gov|accessdate=11 December 2014}} ;Presidential election re-count {{see also|2004 United States election voting controversies#Objection to certification of Ohio's electoral presidential election]].{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2005/roll007.xml|title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 7|publisher=Clerk.house.gov|accessdate=11 December 2014}} ;Education Lee is the author of the Shirley A. Chisholm United States-Caribbean Educational Exchange Act, which would enhance U.S. foreign relations with [[CARICOM]] nations. This act directs the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) to develop a comprehensive program that extends and expands existing primary and secondary school initiatives in the Caribbean to provide: (1) teacher training methods; and (2) increased community involvement in school activities.[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?c110:H.R.176] {{dead link|date=December 2014}} The bill is named for former Congresswoman [[Shirley Chisholm]], who helped inspire Lee to become involved in politics when Chisholm ran for the Democratic nomination for President; Lee became the Northern California Chair of the Chisholm campaign. ;Economic On September 29, 2008, Lee was one of 95 Democrats to vote against the defeated [[Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008|Emergency Economic Stabilization Act]].{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2008/roll674.xml|title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 674|publisher=Clerk.house.gov|accessdate=11 December 2014}} However, she voted for a modified version on October 3.{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2008/roll681.xml|title=FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 681|publisher=Clerk.house.gov|accessdate=11 December 2014}} ;Health care Lee was strongly critical of the [[Stupak-Pitts Amendment]], which places restrictions on health insurance plans providing coverage for abortions in the context of the [[Affordable Health Care for America Act]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2009/11/10/MNQ81AHHRA.DTL|title=Health care bill reignites abortion debate|work=SFGate|accessdate=11 December 2014}} ;Housing As a congresswoman for the Bay Area, Barbara Lee has made affordable housing in East Bay area and beyond a top priority. Barbara has supported and backed legislation meant to expand home ownership opportunities, improve public housing quality, and assist the homeless.{{cite web|title=Profiles of Social Workers Assisting Those in Need|url=http://socialworkdegree.case.edu/resources/infographic/10-profiles-of-social-workers/|website=Case Western Reserve University|accessdate=30 September 2014}} ;Social Work On March 15, 2013, Lee announced the official relaunch of the Congressional Social Work Caucus to the 113th Congress as the new chairwoman of the social work caucus.{{Cite web|title = Congresswoman Barbara Announces the Re-launch of the Congressional Social Work Caucus|url = http://socialworkcaucus-lee.house.gov/press-release/congresswoman-barbara-announces-re-launch-congressional-social-work-caucus|website = socialworkcaucus-lee.house.gov|accessdate = 2015-05-15}} ==Personal life and public image== Lee has two grown sons, Tony and Craig, both of whom work in the insurance industry. Tony Lee is the CEO of Dickerson Employee Benefits, one of the nation's largest African-American owned insurance brokerage/consulting firms. [[Duke University School of Law|Duke University]] }} '''Denise L. Majette''' (born May 18, 1955) is an [[United States|American]] politician from the [[U.S. state|state]] of [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. A [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]], she represented [[Georgia's 4th congressional district]] in the [[United States House of Representatives]] from 2003 to 2005. ==Biography== Born in [[Brooklyn]], she attended [[Yale University]] and completed a [[Juris Doctor]] degree at [[Duke University]] in 1979. She began her legal career in North Carolina as a Legal Aid staff attorney and a clinical adjunct law professor at [[Wake Forest University]]. A resident of the [[Atlanta]] suburb of [[Stone Mountain, Georgia|Stone Mountain]] since 1983, Majette worked in private law practice before being named an administrative law judge at the Georgia state board of workers' compensation in 1992. The following year, Georgia Governor [[Zell Miller]] appointed her judge of the State Court of [[DeKalb County, Georgia|DeKalb County]]. Majette held the judgeship for nine years.http://www.blackpast.org/aah/majette-denise-l-1955#sthash.dFSZa625.dpuf She resigned from the judgeship in [[U.S. House election, 2002|2002]] to run for the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House of Representatives]] in {{ushr|Georgia|4|}}, which is based in DeKalb County. In a major upset, she defeated 10-year [[incumbent]] [[Cynthia McKinney]] in the Democratic [[primary election|primary]]. McKinney had attracted controversy due to her comments after the [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks]] and her reported backing by Muslim-American groups which she had said was racial profiling. The primary was also influenced by crossover-Republicans, i.e. Republicans who used their ability to vote in a Democratic caucus in Georgia. Majette, who had never run in a partisan contest before, trounced the seemingly entrenched McKinney by a 58% to 42% margin. Majette's upset win was [[tantamount to election]] in this heavily Democratic, black-majority district. In Congress, Majette's voting record was slightly more moderate than that of McKinney. Nonetheless, she is considered fairly liberal by national Democratic standards. Among other issues, she supports [[affirmative action]], [[Pro-choice|abortion rights]], and legal status for [[illegal immigrant]]s working in the U.S., while she opposes [[school voucher]]s and the [[death penalty]].[http://ontheissues.org/GA/Denise_Majette.htm On the Issues: Denise Majette] ==Runs for higher office and later career== Majette would have likely been able to keep her congressional seat for as long as she wanted, given the 4th's heavy Democratic tilt (only the neighboring Atlanta-based 5th is considered more Democratic). However, after only one term, she decided to run for the [[United States Senate|U.S. Senate]] seat being vacated by [[Zell Miller]], who had been appointed to the seat in 2000 following the death of Republican [[Paul Coverdell]]. Miller's decision not to seek a full term in the Senate had caught the Georgia Democrats by surprise. Majette's announcement that she would seek to replace Miller also caught Democrats by surprise, as she was not on anyone's call list when Democrats began seeking a candidate to replace Miller. Further skepticism among Democrats about the viability of her candidacy surfaced when she announced that "God" had told her to run for the Senate. Majette finished first in the Democratic primary but was forced into a runoff against millionaire businessman Cliff Oxford, which she won. She received important endorsements from Senators [[Mary Landrieu]] of Louisiana and [[Debbie Stabenow]] of Michigan, along with many others in Washington who campaigned and raised money for Majette. Her Senate campaign slogan was "I'll be nobody's Senator, but yours." Majette was the first [[African American]] and the first woman to be nominated for the U.S. Senate in Georgia. In the general election, despite her vigorous attacks against her [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] opponent, 6th District Congressman [[Johnny Isakson]], Majette was soundly defeated, losing by 18 points. A number of factors led to the severe defeat. Majette was badly under financed and had to spend valuable time and money in the runoff. In contrast, Isakson had won the Republican nomination by an unexpectedly large margin. Due to her late entry in the race, she had little time or chance to make up ground on Isakson. A proposed amendment to the Georgia Constitution banning [[same-sex marriage]]s (which Majette opposed) boosted Republican turnout significantly; it not only passed by a wide margin statewide, but carried in every county, even DeKalb. She got little help from the top of the ticket; [[John Kerry]] had effectively ceded Georgia to [[George W. Bush]] early in the presidential campaign. McKinney regained her seat in the 2004 election. While McKinney had made no secret that she wanted her old seat back, it is not known whether Majette's decision to run for the Senate was related to a possible rematch against McKinney. Soon after leaving the House, Majette entered private law practice in Atlanta. In March 2006, Majette announced her candidacy for state School Superintendent of Georgia. She defeated substitute teacher Carlotta Harrell in the primary, garnering 67% of the vote. In the general election, however, Majette lost to Republican incumbent [[Kathy Cox]] by a large margin. On March 28, 2014, the Georgia Supreme Court disbarred Majette, finding she overbilled clients and misled the Court about how much she was owed in fees.[http://beta.mirror.augusta.com/news/crime-courts/2014-03-28/ex-congresswoman-disbarred?v=1396016365] ==Electoral history== [[Image:RepDeniseMajette.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Congressional photo of Denise Majette.]] {| class="wikitable" style="margin:0.5em ; font-size:95%" |+ {{ushr|Georgia|4|}}: 2002 results{{cite web |url=http://clerk.house.gov/member_info/electionInfo/index.html |title=Election Statistics |accessdate=2007-08-08 |publisher=Office of the Clerk of the House of Representatives }} !|Year ! !|Democrat !|Votes !|Pct ! !|Republican !|Votes !|Pct ! |- |[[U.S. House election, 2002|2002]] | |{{Party shading/Democratic}} |{{nowrap|'''Denise L.
