Maxine Waters (D-Calif.). The outspoken [[Post-September 11 anti-war movement|anti-war]] [[leftist|liberal]], who campaigned for [[Ned Lamont]] (D) over Sen. [[Joe Lieberman]] (I-[[Connecticut|Conn.]]) last year, has not picked a favorite. }} {{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/news/politics/politicalintelligence/2008/01/maxine_waters_f.html |title=Maxine Waters for Clinton – 2008 Presidential Campaign Blog – Political Intelligence |accessdate=2009-03-14 |author= |first=Marcella |last=Bombardieri |authorlink= |date=January 29, 2008 |publisher= |pages= |language= |doi= |quote= |work=[[Boston Globe]]}} {{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/news/politics/politicalintelligence/2008/01/maxine_waters_f.html |work=The Boston Globe |title=Maxine Waters for Clinton |first=Marcella |last=Bombardieri |date=January 29, 2008}} Waters later switched her endorsement to Sen. [[Barack Obama]] when his lead in the [[pledged delegate]] count became insurmountable on the final day of primary voting. {{cite news |url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/06/03/the-superdelegate-tally/index.html?hp |work=The New York Times |title=The Superdelegate Tally |first=Julie |last=Bosman |date=June 3, 2008 |accessdate=May 12, 2010}} Waters had a confrontation over an [[earmark (politics)|earmark]] in the [[United States House Committee on Appropriations]] with fellow Democratic congressman [[Dave Obey]] in 2009. The funding request was for a public school employment training center in Los Angeles that was named after her. {{cite news |first=Jared |last=Allen |author2=Mike Soraghan |title=Obey, Waters in noisy floor fight |url=http://thehill.com/leading-the-news/obey-waters-in-noisy-floor-fight-2009-06-25.html |publisher= |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |date=June 25, 2009 |accessdate=2009-06-26 |page= |author= |location= |id= |pages= |language= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |quote= }} In 2011, Waters voted against the [[National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012]] as part of a controversial provision that allows the government and the military to indefinitely detain American citizens and others without trial.{{cite web | last =Sheets | first =Connor | title =NDAA Bill: How Did Your Congress Member Vote? | work =International Business Times | url =http://www.ibtimes.com/ndaa-bill-how-did-your-congress-member-vote-384362?page=1 }} With the retirement of [[Barney Frank]] (D-Massachusetts) in 2012, Waters became the [[ranking member]] of the [[United States House Committee on Financial Services|House Financial Services Committee]]. {{cite news |url=http://thehill.com/blog s/on-the-money/banking-financial-institutions/195645-maxine-waters-in-line-to-take-over-from-frank-on-financial-services |title=Maxine Waters in line to take over from Frank on Financial Services Committee |accessdate=2011-12-07 |author=Bernie Becker |first= |last= |authorlink= |author2=Peter Schroeder |date=November 28, 2011 |publisher= |pages= |language= |doi= |quote= |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]}} {{cite news |url=http://thehill.com/blogs/on-the-money/banking-financial-institutions/195645-maxine-waters-in-line-to-take-over-from-frank-on-financial-services |title=Maxine Waters to Succeed Barney Frank on Banking Panel |accessdate=2013-05-23 |author=Michael R. Crittenden |date=December 4, 2012 |work=[[The Wall Street Journal|WSJ Blog Washington Wire]]}} On July 24, 2013, Waters voted in favor of Amendment 100 included in H.R. 2397 Department of Defense Appropriations Act of 2014.{{cite web | title =FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 412 | work =US House of Representatives | url =http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2013/roll412.xml }} The amendment targeted domestic surveillance activities, specifically that of the [[National Security Agency]], and if ultimately passed would have limited the flexibility of the [[PRISM (surveillance program)|NSA's interpretation of the law to collect sweeping data on U.S. citizens]].{{cite web | title =Why The NSA And President Bush Got The FISA Court To Reinterpret The Law In Order To Collect Tons Of Data | work =Tech Dirt | url =https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20130617/01163623501/why-nsa-president-bush-got-fisa-court-to-reinterpret-law-order-to-collect-tons-data.shtml }} Amendment 100 was rejected 217-205. On March 27, 2014, Waters introduced a discussion draft of the Housing Opportunities Move the Economy Forward Act of 2014 known as the HOME Forward Act of 2014.{{cite news|last=Siegel|first=Robert M.|title=Recently Unveiled "HOME Forward" Housing Act May Signal the End of Fannie and Freddie|url=http://www.natlawreview.com/article/recently-unveiled-home-forward-housing-act-may-signal-end-fannie-and-freddie|accessdate=16 April 2014|newspaper=The National Law Review|date=9 April 2014|author2=Jeremy C. Sahn|author3=Bilzin Sumberg Baena Price & Axelrod LLP}} A key provision of the bill includes the collection of 10 basis points for “every dollar outstanding mortgages collateralizing covered securities” estimated to be approximately $5 billion a year. These funds would be directed to three funds that support affordable housing initiatives, with 75% going to the National [[Housing trust fund]]. The National Housing Trust Fund will then provide block grants to states to be used primarily to build, preserve, rehabilitate, and operate rental housing that is affordable to the lowest income households, and groups including seniors, disabled persons and low income workers. The National Housing Trust was enacted in 2008, but has yet to be funded.{{cite web|title=H.R Bill _______ 113th Congress 2D Session [Discussion Draft] "Housing Opportunities Move the Economy Forward Act 5 of 2014’’ or the ‘‘HOME Forward Act of 2014"|url=http://nlihc.org/sites/default/files/HOME_Forward_Act_2014.pdf|publisher=Government Printing Office, 2014|accessdate=16 April 2014}} ===Rodney King verdict and Los Angeles riots=== When south-central Los Angeles erupted in [[Los Angeles riots of 1992|riots]] — in which 58 were killed — after the [[Rodney King]] verdict in 1992, Waters gained national attention "when she helped deliver relief supplies in Watts and demanded the resumption of vital services."Louise Donahue [http://currents.ucsc.edu/06-07/01-15/convocation.asp Rep. Maxine Waters to speak at annual MLK Convocation on February 20] January 15, 2007 Currents (UC Santa Cruz){{cite web | title =Maxine Water | work =PBS | url =http://www.pbs.org/kcet/tavissmiley/archive/200403/20040301_waters.html }} Waters described the riots as a rebellion, saying "If you call it a riot it sounds like it was just a bunch of crazy people who went out and did bad things for no reason. I maintain it was somewhat understandable, if not acceptable."{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/news/printedition/suncommentary/la-op-wordwatch29apr29,1,3907230.story | work=Los Angeles Times | title=Was it a 'riot,' a 'disturbance' or a 'rebellion'? | first=Swati | last=Pandey | date=April 29, 2007 | accessdate=May 12, 2010}} In her view, the violence was “a spontaneous reaction to a lot of injustice.” In regards to the looting of Korean-owned stores by local black residents, she said: “There were mothers who took this as an opportunity to take some milk, to take some bread, to take some shoes ... They are not crooks.” ===Castro and Cuba=== Waters has visited Cuba a number of times, praised [[Fidel Castro]], and demanded an end to the U.S. trade embargo.{{cite web|title=Waters|url=http://www.thepoliticalguide.com/Profiles/House/California/Maxine_Waters/Views/Cuba/|publisher=The Political Guide}} In 1998 Waters wrote a letter to Castro citing the 1960s and 1970s as “a sad and shameful chapter of our history,” and thanked Castro for providing help to those who needed to “flee political persecution.”{{cite news|title=In Castro's Corner|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/225118/castros-corner/flashback|newspaper=The National Review|date=24 July 2008}} In 1998, Waters wrote an open letter to Fidel Castro asking him not to extradite African-American activist [[Assata Shakur]].{{cite web|website=The Dallas Weekly|author=Jihad Hassan Muhammad|title=‘A Song for Assata’ the FBI hunts hip-hop’s hero|url=http://www.dallasweekly.com/news/national/article_3c971cda-b681-11e2-8943-001a4bcf6878.html|date=May 6, 2013|accessdate=November 8, 2013}}{{cite web|website=World History Archives|title=Congresswoman Waters issues statement on U.S. Freedom Fighter Assata Shakur|author=presumably Maxine Waters|url=http://www.hartford-hwp.com/archives/45a/089.html|date=September 9, 1998|accessdate=November 9, 2013}} After a woman drowned during an attempted escape from Cuba to the U.S. in 1999, leaving a six-year-old son, [[Elian Gonzales]], who survived and requested asylum in the U.S., Waters called on President Bill Clinton to return him at once to Cuba. ===Racial politics=== In 2001, Waters called Los Angeles Mayor [[Richard Riordan]] a "plantation owner." During the [[L.A. riots in 1992]], Waters described the violence as a "spontaneous reaction to injustice." She held "economic, social, cultural, and political" factors responsible and that the riots should rightly be called a "rebellion" or "insurrection."Aldore Collier, "Maxine Waters: Telling It Like It Is in L.A.," ''[[Ebony (magazine)|Ebony]]'' (October 1992), p. 38. Waters co-sponsored Rep. [[John Conyers]]' bill calling for [[reparations for slavery]] to be paid to black Americans.{{cite web | title =H.R. 40 (111th): Commission to Study Reparation Proposals for African-Americans Act | work =[[GovTrack]] | url =http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h111-40 }} ===Government spending=== {{More footnotes|date=July 2014}} In September 2011, Waters called for the implementation of a federal "jobs program of a trillion dollars or more." {{Citation needed|date=July 2014}} "We’ve got to put Americans to work," she said. "That's the only way to revitalize this economy. When people work they earn money, they spend that money, and that's what gets the economy up and going."{{Cite news|url=http://nation.foxnews.com/maxine-waters/2011/09/04/rep-maxine-waters-we-need-spend-trillion-or-more-jobs-program|title=Rep. Maxine Waters: We Need To Spend A Trillion Or More On A Jobs Program|last=Feldman|first=Josh|date=2011|work=|access-date=|via=}} ===Haiti=== Waters opposed the [[2004 Haitian coup d'état|2004 coup d'état in Haiti]] and criticized U.S. involvement.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2004/WORLD/americas/03/01/aristide.claim/|title=Aristide says U.S. deposed him in 'coup d'etat'|publisher=CNN|date=March 2, 2004 | accessdate=May 6, 2010}} Following the coup, Waters led a delegation to the [[Central African Republic]] along with [[TransAfrica Forum]] founder [[Randall Robinson]] and Jamaican member of parliament [[Sharon Hay-Webster]] to meet with Aristide and bring him to Jamaica, where he would remain until May.{{citation|title=Defying Washington: Haiti's Aristide Returns to the Caribbean|url=http://www.pacifica.org/programs/dn/040315.html|date=2004-03-15|accessdate=2011-07-01|periodical=Pacifica Radio}}{{citation|url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20040321/news/news3.html|periodical=Jamaica Gleaner|date=2004-03-21|accessdate=2011-07-01|title=Newsmaker profile - Sharon Hay Webster}}{{citation|url=http://saskatoon.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20040530/aristide_exile_040530?hub=Saskatoon|periodical=CTV News Saskatoon|title=Aristide leaves Jamaica, heads for South Africa|date=2004-05-30|accessdate=2011-07-01}} ===CIA=== Following a 1996 ''[[San Jose Mercury]]'' article alleging the complicity of the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] (CIA) in the Los Angeles [[crack epidemic]] of the 1980s, Waters called for an investigation. Waters questioned whether "U.S.-government paid or organized operatives smuggled, transported and sold it to American citizens."{{cite web |url=http://www.narconews.com/darkalliance/drugs/library/32.htm |title=Drugs |work=[[The Narco News Bulletin]]|first=Maxine|last=Waters |date=August 30, 1996 |accessdate=2009-03-13|quote=What those articles traced, among other things, is the long-term relationship between [[Norwin Meneses]], a [[Nicaragua]]n [[drug trafficker]], [[Danilo Blandon]], a Nicaraguan businessperson connected to the Contra rebels as well as a drug trader, and [[Ricky Ross (drug trafficker)|Ricky Ross]], an American who worked with Blandon distributing crack cocaine in this country. These individuals represent a much broader and more troubling relationship between [[United States Intelligence Community|U.S. intelligence]] and security policy, [[drug smuggling]], and the spread of [[crack cocaine]] into the United States. Letter to [[U.S. Attorney General]] [[Janet Reno]]}} The [[United States Department of Justice]] (DOJ) announced it had failed to find any evidence to support the original story.{{cite book| last =Cockburn| first =Alexander |author2=Jeffrey St Clair| date =October 1, 1999| title =Whiteout: The CIA, Drugs and the Press| publisher =Verso| location = | isbn =1-85984-258-5}} ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'' also concluded after its own extensive investigation that the allegations were not supported by evidence.[http://www.usdoj.gov/oig/special/9712/ch01p1.htm CIA-Contra-Crack Cocaine Controversy] The author of the original story, [[Gary Webb]], was eventually transferred to a different beat and removed from investigative reporting, before his death in 2004.[http://www.fair.org/index.php?page=2056 "Are You Sure You Want to Ruin Your Career?"] Mr Gary Webb was found in his apartment with two bullet holes in his head. His death was declared a suicide. Following these post-publication investigations, Waters read into the Congressional Record a memorandum of understanding in which former President [[Ronald Reagan]]'s CIA director rejected any duty by the CIA to report illegal narcotics trafficking to the Department of Justice.{{cite web |url=http://www.csun.edu/coms/ben/news/cia/7May98/waters2.html |title=Casey |accessdate=2009-03-14 |author= |first=Maxine |last=Waters |date=7 May 1998 |work=[[Congressional Record]]? |publisher=[[California State University Northridge]] |pages=H2970–H2978 |language= |doi=|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20040910214409/http://www.csun.edu/coms/ben/news/cia/7May98/waters2.html |archivedate=Sep 10, 2004 |quote= }}[http://www.csun.edu/coms/ben/news/cia/7May98/waters2.html Casey] Undeterred, Waters told the Los Angeles Times in 1997: "It doesn't matter whether the CIA delivered the kilo of cocaine themselves or turned their back on it to let somebody else do it. They're guilty just the same." The same CIA inspector general then released a second volume to this report, wherein his investigative team admitted that CIA assets traded in cocaine and crack, and that the CIA had pressured Department of Justice agencies (such as the DEA and FBI) to drop or suspend their own drug-related investigations of such assets. ===Iraq War=== Waters voted against the [[Iraq War Resolution]], the 2002 resolution that funded and granted Congressional approval to possible military action against the regime of [[Saddam Hussein]].{{cite web |url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2002/roll455.xml |title=Final Vote Results for Roll Call 455, H J RES 114 To Authorize the Use of United States Armed Forces Against Iraq |accessdate=2009-03-14 |author= |first= |last= |authorlink= |publisher=[[Clerk of the United States House of Representatives]] |date=10 Oct 2002 |work=}} She has remained a consistent critic of the subsequent war and has supported an immediate troop withdrawal from Iraq. Waters asserted in 2007 that President George W. Bush was trying to "set [Congress] up" by continually requesting funds for an "occupation" that is "draining" the country of capital, soldier's lives, and other resources. In particular, she argued that the very economic resources being "wasted" in Iraq were those that might provide universal health care or fully fund President Bush's own "[[No Child Left Behind]]" education bill. Additionally, Waters, representing a congressional district whose [[median income]] falls far below the national average, argued that patriotism alone had not been the sole driving force for those U.S. service personnel serving in Iraq. Rather, "many of them needed jobs, they needed resources, they needed money, so they're there."[http://www.house.gov/apps/list/speech/ca35_waters/FS071022_iraqwar.html] In a subsequent floor speech, Waters told her colleagues that Congress, lacking the votes to override the "inevitable Bush [[veto]] on any Iraq-related legislation," needed to "better [challenge] the administration's false [[rhetoric]] about the Iraq war" and "educate our constituents [about] the connection between the problems in Pakistan, Turkey, and [[Iran]] with the problems we have created in Iraq."[http://www.house.gov/apps/list/speech/ca35_waters/FS071106_iraq.html] A few months prior to these speeches Waters became a [[sponsor (legislative)|cosponsor]] of the [[U.S. House of Representatives|House]] resolution to impeach [[Vice President]] [[Dick Cheney]] for making allegedly "false statements" about the war.[http://washingtontimes.com/national/20070613-113033-5031r.htm Washington Times – Cheney ouster gains backers] ===International lending=== In August 2008, Waters introduced HR 6796, or the "Stop Very Unscrupulous Loan Transfers from Underprivileged countries from Rich Exploitive Funds Act," also known as the Stop VULTURE Funds Act. This would limit the ability of investors in sovereign debt to use U.S. courts to enforce those instruments against a defaulting country. The bill died in committee.[http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h110-6796 (Gov Track)] ===Mandatory minimum sentences=== Waters opposes [[mandatory sentencing|mandatory minimum sentences]].Kenneth Meeks [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-133011863.html Back talk with Maxine Waters (Interview)] Black Enterprise June 1, 2005 ===Criticism of the Tea Party Movement=== Waters has been very critical of the [[Tea Party movement]]. On August 20, 2011, while at a town hall discussing some of the displeasure that supporters of President Obama have had with the Congressional Black Caucus not supporting the president, Waters stated, "This is a tough game. You can’t be intimidated. You can’t be frightened. And as far as I’m concerned, the ‘tea party’ can go straight to Hell ... and I intend to help them get there."{{cite news| url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/maxine-waters-to-tea-party-go-to-hell/2011/08/22/gIQAjgEeWJ_story.html | work=The Washington Post | first=Sally | last=Jenkins | date=August 22, 2011 | title=Maxine Waters to tea party: Go to Hell}}{{cite web | last =Epstein | first =Jennifer | title =Rep. Maxine Waters: Tea party can go to hell | work =Politico | date =Aug 22, 2011 | url =http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0811/61828.html }} ===Allegations of corruption=== According to Chuck Neubauer and Ted Rohrlich writing in the LA Times in 2004, Maxine Waters' relatives had made more than $1 million during the preceding eight years by doing business with companies, candidates and causes that Waters had helped. August 3, 2010 Christian Science Monitor [[Citizens Against Government Waste]] named her the June 2009 Porker of the Month due to her intention to obtain an [[Earmark (politics)|earmark]] for the Maxine Waters Employment Preparation Center.{{cite news|title=Rep. Maxine Waters is CAGW's June Porker of the Month |url=http://www.cagw.org/site/PageServer?pagename=news_porkerofthemonth_2009_June |publisher=[[Citizens Against Government Waste]] |date=April 2009 |accessdate=2009-07-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20090623023939/http://www.cagw.org:80/site/PageServer?pagename=news_porkerofthemonth_2009_June |archivedate=June 23, 2009 }} In 2010, Waters came under investigation for ethics violations and was accused by a House panel of at least one ethics violation related to her efforts to help [[OneUnited Bank]], where her husband had been a director and in which he had stock holdings, receive federal aid.{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-waters-20100731,0,6472045.story?track=rss | work=The Los Angeles Times | title=Maxine Waters faces ethics charges | first1=Richard | last1=Simon | first2=Lisa | last2=Mascaro | date=July 31, 2010}} Waters' husband is a stockholder and former [[Board of directors|director]] of [[OneUnited Bank]] and the bank's executives were major [[campaign contributions|contributors]] to her campaigns. In September 2008, Waters arranged meetings between [[U.S. Treasury Department]] officials and OneUnited Bank, so that the bank could plead for federal cash. It had been heavily invested in [[Freddie Mac]] and [[Fannie Mae]], and its capital was "all but wiped out" after the [[U.S. government]] took them over. The bank received $12 million in [[Troubled Asset Relief Program]] (TARP) money.{{cite news |first=Susan |last=Schmidt |authorlink=Susan Schmidt |title=Waters Helped Bank Whose Stock She Once Owned |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB123682571772404053.html |publisher= |work=[[Wall Street Journal]] |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=2009-03-13|quote=Ms. Waters, who represents inner-city Los Angeles, hasn't made a secret of her family's financial interest in OneUnited. Referring to her family's investment, she said in 2007 during a congressional hearing that for African-Americans, "the test of your commitment to economic expansion and development and support for business is whether or not you put your money where your mouth is."}}{{cite news |first=Eric |last=Lipton |authorlink=Eric Lipton |author2=[[Jim Rutenberg]] |author3=Barclay Walsh |title=Congresswoman, Tied to Bank, Helped Seek Funds |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/13/us/politics/13waters.html?scp=1&sq=OneUnited%20Waters%20Williams&st=cse|publisher= |work=[[New York Times]] |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=2009-03-13 |quote=Top federal regulators say they were taken aback when they learned that a California congresswoman who helped set up a meeting with bankers last year had family financial ties to a bank whose chief executive asked them for up to $50 million in special bailout funds.}} The matter was investigated by the [[United States House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct|House Ethics Committee]],{{cite news |first=Larry |last=Margasak |title=Ethics panel defers probe on Jesse Jackson Jr.|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5isD4Tm-5D4OFcA0LUEPQcnltY46AD9AOHICO2 |publisher= |agency=Associated Press|date=September 16, 2009 |accessdate=2009-09-16}}{{cite news |title=Maxine Waters: House ethics panel extends case of L.A. lawmaker |author=Richard Simon |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-maxine-waters-20120806,0,2362870.story |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=6 August 2012 |accessdate=10 August 2012}} which charged her with violations of the House's ethics rules in 2010. [[House Oversight and Government Reform Committee]] |website=http://www.house.gov/watson/ }} '''Diane Edith Watson''' (born November 12, 1933) is a former [[United States House of Representatives|US Representative]] for {{ushr|CA|33}}, serving from 2003 until 2011. She is a member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]]. The district is located entirely in [[Los Angeles County]] and includes much of [[Central Los Angeles]], as well as such wealthy neighborhoods as [[Los Feliz]]. A native of [[Los Angeles]], Watson is a graduate of the [[University of California, Los Angeles]], and also holds degrees from [[California State University, Los Angeles]] and [[Claremont Graduate University]]. She worked as a psychologist, professor, and health occupation specialist before serving as a member of the [[Los Angeles Unified School District|Los Angeles Unified School Board]] (1975–78). She was a member of the [[California Senate]] from 1978 to 1998, and the [[United States Ambassador to the Federated States of Micronesia|US Ambassador to Micronesia]] from 1999 to 2000. Watson was elected to Congress in a 2001 special election to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Representative [[Julian C. Dixon]]. She was re-elected four times, but retired after the end of the [[111th United States Congress|111th Congress]]. ==Early life, education and career== [[File:Diane Watson.jpg|upright|left|thumb|Earlier photo of Watson]] Born in [[Los Angeles, California]], Watson was raised Catholic.[http://www.votesmart.org/bio.php?can_id=BS021500 Representative Diane E. Watson (CA)] from [[Project Vote Smart]] According to a DNA analysis, some of her ancestors were from the [[Central African Republic]].[http://www.prweb.com/releases/2008/11/prweb1673564.htm Growing Interest in DNA-Based Genetic Testing Among African American with Historic Election of President Elect Barack Obama] She was educated at [[Dorsey High School]], [[Los Angeles City College]] and the [[University of California, Los Angeles]], where she earned her [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in [[Education]] (1956). Watson became a member of [[Alpha Kappa Alpha]]. She earned an [[Master of Science|MS]] from [[California State University, Los Angeles]] in [[School Psychology]] (1967) and a [[PhD]] in [[School leadership|Educational Administration]] from [[Claremont Graduate University]] in 1987. She also attended the [[Kennedy School of Government]] at [[Harvard University]]. Watson taught [[elementary school]] and was a [[school psychologist]] in the [[Los Angeles Unified School District|Los Angeles public schools]]. She has lectured at [[California State University, Long Beach]] and [[California State University, Los Angeles]]. She was a health occupation specialist with the [[California Department of Education]]'s Bureau of Industrial Education. Watson was elected to the [[California State Senate]] from 1978 to 1998. The longtime chair of the Health and Human Services Committee, she gained a reputation as an advocate for [[health care]] for the [[poverty|poor]] and [[child]]ren. Term limited, she was replaced by [[Kevin Murray (politician)|Kevin Murray]]. When, in 1988, the US government proposed the addition of the category of "bi-racial" or "[[multiracial]]" to official documents and statistics, some African American organizations and African American leaders such as Watson and Representative [[Augustus Hawkins]] were particularly vocal in their rejection and opposition of the category. They feared massive defection from the [[African American]] self-designation. In 1992, Watson ran for the [[Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors]]. After a hard-fought campaign that often turned negative, Watson narrowly lost to former Supervisor [[Yvonne Burke]], who was supported by US Representative [[Maxine Waters]]. President [[Bill Clinton]] appointed her [[United States Ambassador]] to [[Federated States of Micronesia|Micronesia]] in 1999. ==US House of Representatives== ===Committee assignments=== *'''[[United She was one of the 31 members of the House who voted not to count the [[Electoral College (United States)|electoral vote]]s from [[Ohio]] in the [[United States presidential election, 2004]].[http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2005/roll007.xml FINAL VOTE RESULTS FOR ROLL CALL 7] In 2006, the ''[[National Journal]]'' ranked Watson as the most [[Social liberalism|liberal]] member of Congress.[http://www.vote-smart.org/issue_rating_detail.php?r_id=3655 National Journal - Composite Liberal Score] On the issue of [[Cherokee Freedmen]] membership in the Cherokee tribe, Watson noted that 20,000 Cherokee lived in California. She opposed the [[Cherokee Nation]]'s March 2007 vote to amend its [[constitution]] to limit membership to only those descendants with at least one [[Native Americans in the United States|Indian]] ancestor on the [[Dawes Roll]]. She noted that when [[freedmen]] were granted [[citizenship]] in the tribe in 1866 by a treaty which the Cherokees made with the US government, it was without restriction to those freedmen with Indian ancestry. Appeals to the Cherokee Nation's position were pending, in part because the tribe excluded descendants of Cherokee freedmen and intermarried whites from voting on the amendment. In June 2007 Watson introduced a bill to sever US relations with the tribe and revoke its [[Native American gambling enterprises|gaming privileges]] unless the Cherokee restored membership in the tribe to descendants of Cherokee freedmen.{{cite news|first=Gillian |last=Flaccus |authorlink= |author= |coauthors= |title=Cherokee identity fight reaches Calif. |url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2007/09/27/cherokee_identity_fight_reaches_calif/ |agency=Associated Press |publisher=Boston Globe |location=[[Boston, Massachusetts]] |id= |pages= |page= |date=September 27, 2007 |accessdate=2008-12-28 |language= |quote= |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20090903120550/http://www.boston.com:80/news/nation/articles/2007/09/27/cherokee_identity_fight_reaches_calif/ |archivedate=September 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} ==Political campaigns== In the [[2008 Democratic primary]], Watson's district went overwhelmingly for [[Illinois]] Senator [[Barack Obama]] by a margin of 61-29. As a [[superdelegate]], Watson continued to support [[New York]] [[US Senator|Senator]] [[Hillary Clinton]]. Johnson]] | party=[[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] | birth_date= September 11, 1931 | death_date={{death date and age|1993|1|24|1931|9|11}} | religion= | spouse= | children= | alma_mater = }} '''Geraldine "Gerri" Whittington''' (September 11, 1931 – January 24, 1993) was the personal executive [[secretary]] to [[President of the United States|President]] [[Lyndon B. Johnson]], and was the first [[African-American]] secretary in the [[White House]]. Johnson was famous for working long hours and insisting his assistants worked long hours as well. When [[John F. Kennedy assassination|John F. Kennedy was assassinated]] and Johnson became president, he requested a new slate of secretaries. He saw Whittington working in a government office, and requested that his "special assistant" [[Jack Valenti]] get her home phone number. Johnson called her unannounced one evening, and requested that she come in that night for an interview. According to audiotapes of Johnson's phone calls, Whittington at first thought the call was a joke, but came to believe that it really was the president on the line.Jon Margolis, ''The Last Innocent Year: America in 1964: The Beginning of the "Sixties"''; New York: William Morrow & Co., 1999; p. 60.
"Gerri? Where are you?"
"I'm at home. Who's this?"
"This is the president."
"Oh, I think someone's playing with me."
 She applied for the job and was offered the position. Having a black woman in the White House was very unusual in the early 1960s. Johnson wanted to advertise the fact that he'd hired a black woman, but chose not to call a [[news conference]]. Instead, he arranged for Whittington to appear on the television [[game show]] ''"[[What's My Line?]]"'', wherein contestants attempted to guess her profession. This may have seemed less overt, but probably exposed her to more viewers than if a standard press conference had been held. Whittington appeared on episode #696 of the game show ''[[What's My Line?]]'' on January 19, 1964. She was the first contestant. The mystery guest that evening was Van Heflin and the panel consisted of Arlene Francis, Steve Allen, Dorothy Kilgallen and Bennett Cerf. After Whittington signed the blackboard as "Jerri Whittington," she told host John Daly that she was from [[West River, Maryland]]. Whittington's occupation was shown on the screen as "Secretary to President Johnson." After her game, she described President Lyndon Johnson with the following words, "great warmth, fair, kind, a perfectionist." Later Whittington appeared in several magazines, including ''[[Jet (magazine)|Jet]]'' and ''[[Sepia (magazine)|Sepia]]''. She was the first person to learn that Justice [[Thurgood Marshall]] had been nominated by President Johnson to the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]]. Minutes before LBJ made the official announcement, he took his nominee down to her office and said, "Here's the next Supreme Court Justice!" She told friends that she thanked the President for making the choice of the first Black court justice. After suffering a stroke at age 38, Ms. Whittington died of cancer in Washington, DC, on January 24, 1993, on the same day as Justice Thurgood Marshall.{{citation|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1355/is_n16_v83/ai_14164651/|title=LBJ's exec secretary dies.|first=|last= |date=1993-02-14|work=[[Jet (magazine)|JET]]|accessdate=2009-05-04}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Whittington, Jerri}} [[Category:1931 births]] [[Category:1993 deaths]] [[Category:African-American women in politics]] [[Category:Personal secretaries to the President of the United States]] [[Category:Contestants on American game shows]] [[Category:People from Anne Arundel County, Maryland]] [[Category:Lyndon B.
